page.text: Changes to the plan along with a response to the review comments are provided below (in bold).

i.b: City of Ann Arbor – Community Services Area, Planning & Development Services Unit,

text.i: Site Plan:
The site consists of five separate parcels; these parcels must be combined as a condition
of approval.
Existing/proposed height is incorrect in the Comparison Chart.

text.b: The existing and proposed building heights are updated in the Comparison Chart.

text.i: Barrier free spaces are all concentrated toward the center of the parking lot. Consider
adding/moving some for more even distribution.

text.b: The proposed barrier free spaces are redistributed over the parking field to
provide more accessible service to all buildings.

text.i: Bicycle parking in the rear will be difficult for customers to find. Consider re- locating
some to the landscape islands near the center sidewalk(s) from Washtenaw.

text.b: Seven (7) bicycle parking spaces are relocated to the front center landscape island
to provide better bicycle parking for customers entering from Washtenaw.

text.i: In accordance with our Citizen Participation Ordinance requirements, provide a
summary of all public comment (if any) received to date.

text.b: See attached letter from Tower Construction addressing Citizen comments.

page.text: City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan

text.b: w w w . n e d e r v e l d . c o m

text.i: Fence along the rear property line adjacent to the residential neighborhood is in poor
condition. Please indicate any plans for improvement/replacement.

text.b: The existing fence along the rear property line is now marked for removal and
replacement with a proposed 6’ high vinyl fence. Refer to Sheet C-205.

text.i: A Development Agreement may be prepared for this project.

i.b: City of Ann Arbor – Fire Department Review, August 11, 2014

text.i: Addressing:
Address shall be clearly visible when approaching the building. Address numbers shall be
provided on all south alley doors.

text.b: Address numbers will be visible on the north and south sides of the building. A note is
added to the Site Plan notes on sheet C-205.

text.i: Hydrant Coverage:
Proposed Building No. 1 does not meet the 250’ hydrant radius requirement.
Entire footprint of building does not meet the 400’ hose lay requirement from a
supporting hydrant.

text.b: An additional fire hydrant is added along Pittsfield Boulevard to provide sufficient
coverage to proposed Building No. 1. Refer to C-400 for hydrant location and coverage.

text.i: Fire Department Connection (FDC):
Falls within the 100’ distance requirement from a supporting hydrant.
Fire Protection Alarm & Detection Systems:
Water flow horn/strobe alarm shall be located above the FDC. The Alarm system
shall meet the minimum requirements in NFPA 72, 2007 Edition and all other
referenced standards.

text.b: A note is added to the Site Utility Notes. Refer to sheet C-400.

text.i: Knox Box:
A single Knox Box is permitted to be mounted near the FDC for emergency access to each
business as well as the fire suppression control room.

text.b: A Knox Box will be provided. Refer to sheet C-205.

page.text: City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan
Ann Arbor • Chicago • Columbus • Grand Rapids • Holland

text.b: w w w . n e d e r v e l d . c o m

text.i: Construction Sequencing:
Hydrants shall be in service and approved during construction.
Hydrants providing protection coverage for the building shall be in service and
approved by both Planning and Fire Department before Fire Department will
support permit issuance for new construction phase and before combustible
material are placed on the job site.
Storage area for construction materials shall not interfere with fire/emergency site
access.

text.b: The notes above are added to the Site Utility Notes on sheet C-400.

i.b: City of Ann Arbor – Public Services Area – Project Management Review, August 14, 2014

text.i: Site Plan:
Traffic Impact Study must be provided.

text.b: The traffic impact study is provided with this submittal.

text.i: Because Washtenaw Avenue is under MDOT jurisdiction, TIS must be reviewed
/approved by MDOT.
There needs to be a confirmation by a Registered Engineer that new driveways on
Pittsfield and Yost meet applicable AASHTO standards with regard to intersection sight
distance.

text.b: Sight distance triangles are provided. Refer to sheet C-205

text.i: The internal connecting drive in front of the building creates a straight shortcut from
Pittsfield Blvd to Yost. To discourage cut-through and high speeds, traffic calming
devices should be incorporated in the design of this road.

text.b: Stop signs and cross walk striping are now proposed along the front building drive

i.b: City of Ann Arbor – Solid Waste and Recycling Review, August 6, 2014

text.i: Site Plan:
The “Proposed Trash Carts & Proposed Dumpster Pad” does not include recycling. The
Petitioner needs to provide the area where these containers will be located.

text.b: The proposed location of the recycling enclosure is provided on the plan.

text.i: Type and size of container(s) inside the “Proposed Trash Carts & Proposed Dumpster
Pad” is not included. The Petitioner needs to provide the number, type and size of
container(s) to be used.

text.b: A proposed 8’x 17’ recycling enclosure is added to the plan. Refer to sheet C-205.

i.b: City of Ann Arbor – Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control, August 6, 2014

text.i: Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control:
The location and type of soil on the project site is indicated on Sheet 2. The site plan
must also include data like the distribution, erodibility, drainage, etc.

text.b: A site soil analysis is provided on sheet C-201.

text.i: The legend on Sheet 5 indicates that the symbol for an inlet filter is a gray box with the
Number 40. However, the inlet symbols on the site plan are different sized circles with
and without the number 40. Some inlets have the number 40, but no symbol. The symbol
for inlet filters must be uniform throughout the plan.

text.b: The grading legend on sheet C-300 is revised.

text.i: The plan indicates that the alley along the south side of the site will remain in place.
However, the site grades indicate that sediment could wash over the alley from the
construction site to the property to the south. Silt fence should be called for along the
south property line.

text.b: The alley along the south side of the site is to be reconstructed as part of this
project. An existing concrete wall along the south property line will remain and
will prevent sediment from leaving the site.

text.i: The removal of existing features and the installation of new storm sewer are proposed
along the west side of the property outside of the limits of the silt fence. The silt fence
location must be revised in this area to surround all disturbed area within the limits of
grading.

text.b: The silt fence is revised along the west property line, as requested. Refer to C-300.

text.i: A detailed estimated total cost of the required controls during construction, including
dust emission control must be provided on the plan.

text.b: Soil erosion control costs are provided on sheet C-300.

text.i: The estimated total cost of protecting all exposed soil surfaces from erosion should
construction discontinue must be provided on the plan.

text.b: Permanent seed and mulch costs are provided on sheet C-300.

text.i: Provide an estimate of the amount of excavation and fill involved on the site plan.

text.b: An estimate of the amount of excavation and fill is provided on sheet C-300

text.i: The plan shows five (5) different access points to the construction site. They are off of
Pittsfield Blvd, Washtenaw Ave., Yost Blvd., and both ends of the alley at the south end
of the site. The site plan must indicate the specific access points to the site, and close off
all other area with silt fence. In addition, a mud tracking surface must be provided at

page.text: City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan
Ann Arbor • Chicago • Columbus • Grand Rapids • Holland

text.b: w w w . n e d e r v e l d . c o m

text.i: each construction entrance, and include a detail on the site plan. If a gravel mud
tracking mat is to be used, include non-woven geotextile material beneath the gravel to
be effective. If an existing driveway will be used for access, clearly label as “Driveway
to be used during construction.”

text.b: Site access is reduce to two (2) points, both located along Pittsfield Blvd. Limestone
tracking surfaces with non-woven geotextile underlayment will be installed at both
of these access points. All other points of access will be restricted with silt fencing.

text.i: Show proposed staging, storage and stockpile areas. Stockpiles shall be adequately
protected from erosion and sediment runoff.

text.b: No topsoil storage or stockpile areas are proposed for this project.

text.i: Provide a note stating that both internal and external streets will be cleaned of any
tracked mud immediately following each mud-tracking occurrence.

text.b: This note is added to the Soil Erosion/Sediment Control Notes on sheet C-300.

text.i: Provide a timing and construction sequence of each proposed earth change. The
sequence of construction for the site shall include installation of temporary and
permanent soil erosion and sediment control measures, stripping and clearing, rough
grading, installation and stabilization of storm water management systems, construction
of utilities, roads, infrastructure, and buildings, final grading and landscaping, and
removal of temporary soil erosion and sediment control measures. The sequence of
construction shall identify all proposed phasing consistent with the approved site plan,
final preliminary plat, or PUD site plan. A soil erosion and sedimentation control pre-
grading meeting should be included as the first item in the sequence of construction.

text.b: Construction sequence and timing is provided on sheet C-300. The proposed
project will be constructed in a single phase.

text.i: Per Chapter 63, Section 5:659(12), please include a program proposal for the continued
maintenance of all permanent soil erosion and sedimentation control measures that
remain after project completion, including the designation of the person or party
responsible for the maintenance. Maintenance responsibilities shall become a part of
any sales or exchange agreement for the land on which the permanent soil erosion and
sedimentation control measures are located.

text.b: A schedule for continued maintenance of permanent SESC measures and storm
water quality measures is provided on sheet C-300.

text.i: It appears that this site will exceed 5 acres in disturbance, and therefore will require an
NPDES/NOC permit from the State of Michigan. Per the requirements of the NPDES
permit, inspections will be performed by a certified MDEQ Storm Water Operator at
least once a week and immediately following each precipitation event. The written
reports must be maintained onsite. Please note these requirements on the plans.

text.b: This note is added to the Soil Erosion/Sediment Control Notes on sheet C-300.

text.i: Identify a location for concrete washouts that will not discharge concrete wash offsite or
into the storm sewer system, and provide a construction quality detail for the device.

text.b: The proposed temporary concrete washout area and detail are provided

page.text: We trust that you will find the above comments acceptable, and we look forward to your
approval of the plans. Should you have any questions or concerns with these responses please
feel free to contact us for clarification.

Felino Pascual & Associates, Inc., Felino Pascual

Pittsfield Retail Site Plan (WCWRC project no. 1617)
City of Ann Arbor, Washtenaw County, Michigan

page.text: Changes to the plan along with a response to the review comments are provided below (in bold).

text.i: The engineer's certificate of outlet was not accompanied by corresponding calculations or
documentation.

text.b: An analysis and summary of the existing vs. proposed runoff is provided on sheet C-

text.i: The soil borings for the site, in particular in the vicinity of the detention basin, should be
included with the next design plan submission.

text.b: The results of the site geotechnical investigation are provided with this submittal.

text.i: Design details regarding the water quality devices for the detention basins should be
included with the plan set. This should include performance characteristics, flow capacity,
and type.

text.b: Design details and sizing calculations for the mechanical treatment device are

text.i: There is a portion of the impervious surfaces that is freely releasing from the site. The peak
discharge from the undetained portion should be calculated for a 100-year storm event and
deducted from the overall maximum discharge rate for the detained portions.

text.b: An analysis and summary of the existing vs. proposed runoff is provided on sheet C-
503. The proposed site improvements redirect the majority of the building runoff to
storm water detention basin 1, reducing the 100-yr peak discharge rate by 50%.
Please also note that the peak discharge rate for the site is being reduced by 94% as a
result of the proposed storm water management facilities.

text.i: The bio-retention areas should be shown and labelled on the storm water management
plan. The volume calculations for each area should be shown along with a planting plan.

text.b: Sheet C-502 is created to show the bioretention details and calculations.

text.i: Please note the detention basin stone bedding void ratio may be 30% as opposed to the
20% shown.

text.b: The underground detention calculations are revised to reflect a 30% void ratio.

text.i: The initial submittal fee was paid to the order of the WCRC, not our office. I am returning
the check and future checks should be addressed to WCWRC.

text.b: A new check is provided with this submittal.

text.i: Current review fees total $475.00, with no outstanding balance. Please remit these fees
upon receipt of the accompanying invoice.

text.b: A check in the amount of $475 is provided with this submittal.

page.text: We trust that you will find the above comments acceptable, and we look forward to your
approval of the plans. Should you have any questions or concerns with these responses please
feel free to contact us for clarification.
AF Jonna Development & Management Co., Arkan Jonna
Felino Pascual & Associates, Inc., Felino Pascual
Washtenaw Avenue between Pittsfield Boulevard and Yost Boulevard
In accordance with your request, we have completed the subsurface investigation related to the proposed
storm-water detention infiltration system at the Proposed Pittsfield Retail Development in Ann Arbor,
Michigan. We understand the proposed development will include the construction of three underground
detention areas as part of the overall stormwater management system. The detention systems, 1, 2, and 3
are to be constructed at approximate invert depths of 6 feet, 8 feet, and 8 feet respectively in the northern
parking lot and southern alleyway areas.
The purpose of the supplemental exploration is to determine the soil types, estimated infiltration rates,
and groundwater table in order to provide recommendations relating to the design of the proposed
Tower Construction, in conjunction with G2 Consulting Group, LLC (G2), selected the number, depth,
and location of the soil borings based on the proposed locations of the underground detention areas. We
performed one soil boring in each of the three detention system areas, B-01, B-02, and B-03, identified by
their respective detention system number. A G2 representative marked the soil boring locations in the
field by use of GPS assisted mobile technology and conventional taping methods prior to drilling
The soil borings were drilled using a truck-mounted rotary drilling rig. Continuous flight, 2-1/4-inch
inside diameter, hollow-stem augers were used to advance the boreholes. Within each soil boring, soil
samples were obtained at intervals of 2-1/2 feet within the upper 10 feet and at intervals of 5 feet below
that depth. These samples were obtained by the Standard Penetration Test method ASTM D 1586, which
involves driving a 2-inch diameter split-spoon sampler into the soil with a 140-pound weight falling 30
inches. The sampler is generally driven three successive 6-inch increments with the number of blows for
each increment recorded. The number of blows required to advance the sampler the last 12 inches is
termed the Standard Penetration Resistance (SPT) Number (N or N-value). The blow counts for each 6-
inch increment and the resulting N-value are presented on the individual soil boring logs.
The soil samples were placed in sealed containers in the field and brought to the laboratory for testing and
classification. During drilling operations, the drilling crew maintained logs of the encountered subsurface
conditions, including changes in stratigraphy and observed groundwater levels to be used in conjunction
with our analysis of the subsurface conditions. The final boring logs are based on the field logs and
laboratory soil classification and test results. After completion of drilling operations, the boreholes were
backfilled with excavated soil and capped with cold patch.
Representative soil samples were subjected to laboratory testing pertinent to the determination of soil
parameters related to the design of underground storm water detention areas. An experienced
geotechnical engineer classified the samples in general conformance with the Unified Soil Classification
Laboratory testing included moisture contents, unconfined compressive strength, and fines
The unconfined compressive strengths were determined by ASTM Test
Method D2166 and a spring-loaded hand penetrometer. Per ASTM Test Method D2166, the unconfined
compressive strength of cohesive soils is determined by axially loading a small cylindrical soil sample
under a slow rate of strain. The unconfined compressive strength is defined as the maximum stress
applied to the soil sample before shear failure. If shear failure does not occur prior to a total strain of 15
percent, the unconfined compressive strength is defined as the stress at a total strain of 15 percent.
The hand penetrometer estimates the unconfined compressive strength to a maximum of 4-1/2 tons per
square foot (tsf) by measuring the resistance of the soil sample to the penetration of a calibrated spring-
loaded cylinder. The fines content was determined based on ASTM D1140.
The results of the moisture content, unconfined compressive strength, and percent fines laboratory tests
are indicated on the boring logs at the depths the samples were obtained. Unconfined compressive
strength test results are graphically presented on Figure No. 4. We will hold the soil samples for 60 days
from the date of this report. If you would like us to retain the samples beyond this date, or if you would
like the samples to be returned to you, please let us know.
The proposed storm water management system will be comprised of three detention areas. Detention area
1 will be located on the eastern half of the north parking lot area, detention area 2 is to be located within
the western half of the north parking lot area, and detention area 3 will be located in the alleyway on the
southern portion of the lot. The site is currently developed, surrounded by commercial developments, and
is bounded by residential properties to the south, Pittsfield Boulevard to the west, Washtenaw Avenue to
the north, and Yost Boulevard to the east.
Approximately 4 to 7 inches of bituminous concrete underlain by 4 to 6 inches of aggregate base are
present at the ground surface of the soil borings. Fill, consisting of sand, silty sand and silty clay, are
present below the pavement section and extend to depths of 3 to 9 feet below existing grade. Native silty
clay is present beneath the fill soils and extends to the explored depths.
Granular fill soils are generally loose to medium compact with respect to relative density with Standard
Penetration Test N-values ranging from 5 to 21 blows per foot (bpf). However, the silty sand fill witin
boring B-3 between 3-1/2 to 5-1/2 feet below grade is very loose in compactness with an N-value of 4
bpf. The silty clay fill is generally stiff in consistency with moisture contents ranging from 18 to 25
percent and unconfined compressive strengths of 2,500 pounds per square foot (psf). The native silty clay
is generally very stiff to hard in consistency with natural moisture contents ranging from 13 to 20 percent,
a dry density of 112 pounds per cubic foot (pcf), and unconfined compressive strengths ranging from
The stratification depths shown on the soil boring logs represent the soil conditions at the boring
locations. Variations of the soil conditions may occur away from the soil boring locations. We have
prepared the boring logs on the basis of laboratory classification and testing as well as the field log of the
soils encountered. The Soil Boring Location Plan, Plate No. 1, and Soil Boring Log, Figure No. 1
through 3, and Unconfined Compression Test, Figure No. 4, are attached with this letter report. General
Notes Terminology defining the nomenclature used on the soil boring logs and elsewhere in this report
Groundwater observations were performed during and upon completion of the drilling operations.
Groundwater was observed within soil boring B-03 at a depth of 3 feet during drilling operations. Upon
completion of drilling operations, soil boring B-03 collapsed at a depth of 4 feet due to seepage of water
into the borehole. No groundwater was observed during or upon completion of drilling operations in soil
Within boring B-03, the groundwater appears to be in a perched condition within the upper granular fill
overlying the relatively impermeable native silty clay. We do not believe the observed groundwater
conditions are indicative of the long-term groundwater table in this area. An estimate of historical
groundwater levels may be made based on the soil color change from the brown soils, indicating an
aerobic condition where free oxygen is available, to grays, indicating an anaerobic condition where free
oxygen is not available. This color change occurs at an approximate depth of 9 feet below existing grade
within boring B-03 and below depths of 10 feet and 12 feet within borings B-01 and B-02, respectively.
Fluctuations in perched and long term groundwater levels should be anticipated due to seasonal variations
and following periods of prolonged precipitation. It should also be noted that groundwater observations
made during drilling operations in predominantly cohesive soils are not necessarily indicative of the static
groundwater level. This is due to the low permeability of such soils and the tendency of drilling
operations to seal off the natural paths of groundwater flow.
We anticipate the soils at the invert depths of the underground detention areas will primarily consisting of
native silty clay. Since the subsurface soils at the proposed infiltration depths are generally comprised of
relatively impermeable native silty clay, we anticipate that the subgrade soils on site will not allow for
storm water to drain freely. We anticipate the native silty clay would have hydraulic conductivities
We appreciate the opportunity to be of service to you and look forward to discussing the soil conditions
presented herein. In the meantime, if you have any questions regarding this report or any other matter
pertaining to the project, please call us.

Unless otherwise noted, all terms herein refer to the Standard Definitions presented in ASTM 653.
The major soil constituent is the principal noun, i.e. clay, silt,
sand, gravel. The second major soil constituent and other
minor constituents are reported as follows:
If clay content is sufficient so that clay dominates soil properties, clay becomes the principal noun with the other
major soil constituent as modifier, i.e. sandy clay. Other minor soil constituents may be included in accordance
with the classification breakdown for cohesionless soils, i.e. silty clay, trace sand, little gravel.
Consistency of cohesive soils is based upon an evaluation of the observed resistance to deformation under load and
not upon the Standard Penetration Resistance (N).
Relative Density of cohesionless soils is based upon the evaluation of the Standard Penetration Resistance (N),
modified as required for depth effects, sampling effects, etc.
Auger Sample – Cuttings directly from auger flight
Liner Sample with liner insert 3 inches in length
Shelby Tube sample - 3 inch diameter unless otherwise noted
Piston Sample - 3 inch diameter unless otherwise noted
Rock Core - NX core unless otherwise noted
STANDARD PENETRATION TEST (ASTM D 1586) - A 2.0 inch outside-diameter, 1-3/8 inch inside-diameter split barrel
sampler is driven into undisturbed soil by means of a 140-pound weight falling freely through a vertical distance of 30 inches.
The sampler is normally driven three successive 6-inch increments. The total number of blows required for the final 12 inches of
penetration is the Standard Penetration Resistance (N).
This memorandum presents the results of a Traffic Impact Assessment (TIA) for the proposed Pittsfield Retail
development site in the City of Ann Arbor, Michigan. The project site is located on the south side of
Washtenaw Avenue (BUS US-23 / BL I-94) between Pittsfield Boulevard and Yost Boulevard. The existing
site currently includes 55,265 square feet (SF) or retail space and is being proposed for an additional 18,894
SF of retail space. The existing site access points to Washtenaw Avenue and Yost Boulevard will be
maintained, while the northern access point to Pittsfield Boulevard will be relocated approximately 100 feet to
the south to align with the northern site driveway to Yost Boulevard. Additionally, the development plans
include elimination of the exit only driveway to Pittsfield Boulevard and the existing service drive that runs
along the length of the site.
The Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) has jurisdiction over Washtenaw Avenue and has
required a TIA for the project to evaluate traffic operations with respect to the proposed plan. This TIA has
been completed to identify the impacts (if any) of this project on the following study intersections:
Washtenaw Avenue & Pittsfield Boulevard / Arborland Egress Driveway,
Washtenaw Avenue & Yost Boulevard / Arborland Driveway,
Washtenaw Avenue & SB US-23 Exit Ramp,
Washtenaw Avenue & NB US-23 Exit Ramp, and
The scope of the study was developed based on Fleis & VandenBrink’ s (F&V) knowledge of the study area,
understanding of the development program, accepted traffic engineering practice, and methodologies
published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE). Input and agreement on the study scope was
also achieved through conversations with MDOT. The study analyses were completed using Synchro and
Existing vehicular turning movement counts were collected by F&V subconsultant, Traffic Data Collection, Inc.
collected during the weekday PM (4:00 PM to 6:00 PM) peak period at the study intersections. F&V also
collected an inventory of existing lane use and traffic controls and obtained existing traffic signal timing
information from MDOT. The existing PM peak hour traffic volumes were identified based on the data
collected. Peak hour turning movement volumes at each intersection were utilized for this study, and the
through volumes were balanced upward where appropriate.
Existing peak hour vehicle delays and Levels of Service (LOS) were calculated at the study intersections
using Synchro (Version 8) traffic analysis software. This analysis was based on the existing lane use and
traffic control, the existing peak hour traffic volumes, and the methodologies presented in the Highway
Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM). Typically, LOS D is considered acceptable, with LOS A representing minimal
delay, and LOS F indicating failing conditions. Additionally, SimTraffic network simulations were reviewed to
evaluate network operations and vehicle queues.
All study intersections currently operate under the SCOOT traffic control system which is an adaptive traffic
control system that coordinates the operation of traffic signals along the corridor to provide good progression.
In order to replicate this in Synchro and SimTraffic, all intersections were coded as actuated-coordinated
signals and were optimized to a cycle length of 144 seconds at the recommendation of the City of Ann Arbor.
The results of the existing conditions analysis are attached and summarized in Table 1.
The results of the existing conditions analysis indicate that all study intersections currently operate acceptably
at an overall LOS D or better except the intersection of Washtenaw Avenue & Huron Parkway which currently
operates at an overall LOS E. Additionally, several approaches and movements at the study intersections
currently operate at a LOS E or F. At the intersection of Washtenaw Avenue & Huron Parkway, all
approaches currently operate at a LOS E or F. At the intersections of Washtenaw Avenue & Pittsfield
Boulevard and Washtenaw Avenue & Yost Boulevard, the minor street approaches currently operate at a
Review of the network simulation indicates that the approaches indicated above to operate at a LOS E or F,
currently experience significant vehicle queues throughout the majority of the PM peak period. At the
intersection of Washtenaw Avenue & Huron Parkway, vehicle queues are observed on all approaches
throughout the duration of the peak hour. At the existing site driveways, vehicle queues are observed from
the northbound approaches of Pittsfield Boulevard and Yost Boulevard that currently block site access for
approximately 63% and 27% of the PM peak hour, respectively.
As this development is proposed within the next year, and based on stagnant traffic growth patterns in
southeast Michigan, future background conditions (without the proposed development) are assumed equal to
existing conditions. Any potential background growth is accounted for based on the upward balancing of
The number of PM peak hour vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed development expansion
was determined based on data published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in Trip

text.i: Generation, 9
th

page.text: Edition and the Trip Generation Handbook, 2

text.i: nd

page.text: Edition. As the site is presently occupied by
55,265 SF of retail space, the site is currently generating peak hour traffic volumes that are included in the
peak hour traffic counts described in the existing conditions analyses. In order to determine the potential
impact of the proposed project, the net increase in vehicle trips associated with the additional retail space
As is typical of retail uses, a portion of the site-generated trips are already present on the adjacent road
network and are interrupted to visit the site. These trips are known as “pass-by” trips and account for a
percentage of the total site-generated traffic. Pass-by trips result in turning movements at the site driveways,
but do not increase traffic volumes on the adjacent road network. The trip generation forecast / comparison is
shown in Table 2 and indicates that the additional retail space would result in 70 additional site-generated
trips of which 46 would be new to the adjacent road network.
These trips, shown in Table 2, were assigned to the study intersections based on existing traffic patterns to
establish the future traffic volumes. These patterns indicate that approximately 55% of site traffic would enter
/ exit the site to / from the east during the PM peak hour. The site-generated traffic volumes were distributed
through the intersections along Washtenaw Avenue based on existing turning movement percentages.
Future peak hour vehicle delays and LOS were calculated at the study intersections based on the future traffic
volumes with the proposed additional retail space, the existing lane use and traffic control, and the
methodologies of the HCM 2000. The results of this analysis indicate that the proposed project would not
have a significant impact on the study intersections and driveways. Future vehicle delays and LOS as shown
in Table 3 would be similar to existing conditions and any increases would not be discernable.
The intersection approaches and movements that currently operate at a LOS E or F will continue to operate at
a LOS E or F under future conditions. The proposed retail expansion will increase traffic at the study
intersections by less than 2%; therefore improvements that would be required to mitigate future operations
are considered to be regional and beyond the scope of this study.

text.i: Pass-By
Pass-By
Pass-By

page.text: At the site driveways, all movements and approaches will operate acceptably at a LOS C or better. Review of
the network simulation indicates that the driveways to Pittsfield Boulevard and Yost Boulevard will be blocked
during approximately 26% and 46% of the PM peak hour, respectively. However, as the majority of traffic
wishing to utilize the Yost Boulevard site driveway will travel to the east on Washtenaw Avenue, they can
utilize the Washtenaw Avenue site driveway during peak periods of congestion. At the Pittsfield Boulevard
site driveway, the relocation of the driveway further south helped to reduce the proportion of time the driveway
is blocked during the PM peak period.
The following are the conclusions of this Traffic Impact Assessment:
1. Several study intersection approaches and movements currently operate unacceptably at a LOS E or F.
2. Future traffic operations with the proposed retail expansion will be similar to existing conditions and minor
changes to vehicle delay and LOS will not be discernable.
3. The proposed retail expansion will increase traffic volumes at the study intersection by less than 2%,
4. The site driveways to Pittsfield Boulevard and Yost Boulevard will be periodically blocked during the PM
Any questions related to this memorandum, study, analyses, and results should be addressed to Fleis &

signal & push buttons all quadrants. No Turn On Red signed for all approach legs.
